mil3.4.10:0.1_0: The Simile of the Making Hand
mil3.4.10:0.3_0: Practice absorption, the happiness of quenching.
mil3.4.10:1.2_0: “Again, one who doesn’t know extinguishment, and one who knows the happiness of extinguishment?”
mil3.4.10:1.3_0: “Great king, if you don’t know extinguishment, you find extinguishment.”
mil3.4.10:1.4_0: “Sir, how does Nāgadatta know and see so that he is unable to extinguishment?”
mil3.4.10:1.5_0: “What do you think, great king? Wouldn’t you know when your hands and feet are painful to sit there?”
mil3.4.10:1.8_0: “Sir, other carves cut off the sound of drums, arched harps, and hearing the sound of hands and feet, I know: ‘These are painful to touch, sir.’
mil3.4.10:1.9_0: “In the same way, great king, those who see extinguishment have heard it, they know and see extinguishment.”
mil3.4.10:4.1_0: The fourth sub-chapter on quenching is finished.
mil3.4.10:5.1_0: and the ten questions on this exposition of the teaching.
